article.title: Dyne
article.paragraph: other usesThedyne(symbol "dyn", from Greek ,dynamis, meaning power, force) is aUnits of measurementunitofForce (physics)forcespecified in thecentimetregramsecond system of units(CGS), a predecessor of the modernInternational System of UnitsSI. One dyne is equal to 10micro-newton (unit)N(micronewtons), or to 10 nsn (nanosthenes) in the oldmetretonnesecond system of units. Equivalently, the dyne is defined as "the force required to accelerate amassof onegramat a rate of onecentimetrepersecondsquared":

article.paragraph: The namesdyneandergwere first proposed as units of force and energy in 1861 byJoseph David Everett.cite bookRossiterWilliamDictionary of Scientific Terms1879William Collins, Sons, and CoyLondon and Glasgow109The natural units listed in the same text (see Farad in this reference), are those of the metre-gram-second amu.ClarifyFebruary 2012

The names were reused in 1873 by a Committee of the British Associationcite conferencehttp://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/94452#page/7/mode/1up First Report of the Committee for the Selection and Nomenclature of Dynamical and Electrical Units September 1873 Forty-third Meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science Professor Everett Sir W Thomson Foster Professor GC Professor JC Maxwell Mr GJ Stoney Jenkin Professor Flemming Dr Siemens Mr FJ Bramwell Johna Murray Bradford 223 8 April 2012(of which Everett was reporter) that proposed using the centimetre-gram-second system for electrical and dynamical systems.
